list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because Chargaff used paper chromatography to show that the proportions of adenine (A) and thymine (T) are the same, as are the proportions of guanine (G) and cytosine (C). list.title: Question 2
list.content: What provides evidence that all life on Earth evolved from the same population of cells?A.\hspace{1em}Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells.B.\hspace{1em}Both mitochondria and prokaryotes have a cell wall.C.\hspace{1em}Both eukaryotes and bacteria contain histones.D.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is universal.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All 64 codons of the genetic code are present in all organisms, apart from minor variations indicating that all life evolved from the same original cells  (Choice D).Eukaryotic cells evolved from prokaryotic cells (Choice A) is incorrect as this is the endosymbiotic theory.Choice Bis incorrect as mitochondria do not have a cell wall.Choice Cis incorrect as bacteria do not have histones.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: A strand of nucleotides reads CCUAGAGCUUACCG. Which type of pentose sugar could be found in the nucleotides in the natural composition of this strand?A.\hspace{1em}Deoxyribose onlyB.\hspace{1em}Ribose onlyC.\hspace{1em}Both deoxyribose and riboseD.\hspace{1em}Neither deoxyribose nor ribose
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The nucleotide strand CCUAGAGCUUACCG contains the bases cytosine (C), uracil (U), adenine (A), and guanine (G). While C, A, and G are found in both DNA and RNA, the base uracil is only found in RNA. So, the strand is an RNA strand.RNA contains the pentose sugar ribose. Therefore, ribose is found in the nucleotides in the strand.Choices AandCare incorrect because deoxyribose is only found in DNA, not RNA. The nucleotide strand cannot be DNA because it contains uracil in place of thymine (T).Choice Dis incorrect because the strand is RNA which contains ribose.

list.title: Question 4
list.content: Which statement is correct concerning the structure of DNA?A.\hspace{1em}A phosphate within a nucleotide is covalently bonded to a nitrogenous baseB.\hspace{1em}DNA molecules are made up of two parallel strands running in the same 3'-5' direction, linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary basesC.\hspace{1em}Bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNAD.\hspace{1em}Adenine is complementary to uracil, and cytosine is complementary to guanine
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Covalent bonding between adjacent phosphates and deoxyribose sugars forms the backbone of DNA;Choice Cis correct.Within nucleotides, the phosphate is covalently bonded to the deoxyribose sugar and the sugar is attached to the base;Choice Ais incorrect. DNA molecules are made up of two antiparallel strands (they are parallel but run in opposite directions, one runs 3’-5’ and the other 5’-3’), linked by hydrogen bonds between complementary bases;Choice Bis incorrect. In DNA, adenine is complementary to thymine;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Which of the following processes is most directly involved in the formation of nucleic acids such as DNA?A.\hspace{1em}HydrolysisB.\hspace{1em}CondensationC.\hspace{1em}CatabolismD.\hspace{1em}Translation
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Nucleotides are linked together by condensation reactions to form molecules of DNA (Choice B). The formation of DNA requires the removal of water for the joining of smaller molecules to form a larger molecule.The joining of nucleotides together can also be classified as an anabolic reaction but not as a catabolic reaction (Choice C). Catabolism is the breaking down of a large molecule into a smaller molecule. An example of catabolism is hydrolysis which is a reaction that breaks down a large molecule into a smaller molecule by adding water (Choice A).Translation is a process which follows the transcription of DNA (Choice D). It is where mRNA is used as a template by ribosomes to synthesize polypeptides.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: Which statements are characteristics of a DNA molecule?I.The two strands are identical.II.The two strands are antiparallel to one another.III.The sugar-phosphate backbone is held together by covalent bonds.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A DNA molecule is made up of two antiparallel strands of nucleotides. Antiparallel means that both strands are geometrically parallel but oriented in opposite directions (Option II). One of the strands is in the direction of 5' to 3', whereas the other strand is in the direction of 3' to 5'. The backbones, made of alternating sugar and phosphate groups, are held together by covalent sugar-phosphate bonds (Option III). Both of these strands are joined together by the hydrogen bonds between the complementary base pairs.DNA strands are not identical (Option I) because identical would mean that they have the same nucleotide arrangement, instead they are complementary to each other.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: How does the genetic code provide evidence of universal common ancestry?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code of mitochondria is identical to the genetic code of the nucleus in eukaryotes.B.\hspace{1em}Each amino acid is coded for by only one codon.C.\hspace{1em}Mutations cannot cause changes in the sequence of bases in the genome.D.\hspace{1em}The genetic code is the same across all three domains of life, with just a few exceptions.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The genetic code is largely the same in all known organisms. There are a few exceptions such as mitochondrial DNA which can vary slightly in codon assignments for specific amino acids, and some bacterial species. ThereforeChoice Dis correct .Choice Ais incorrect because the genetic code used in mitochondria is similar to the genetic code used in the nucleus of eukaryotic cells but not entirely the same.Choice Bis incorrect because the genetic code is degenerate. There are 64 possible codons in the genetic code, but only 20 amino acids. As a result, some amino acids are coded for by more than one codon, providing redundancy and flexibility in protein synthesis.Choice Cis incorrect because mutations are changes in the genetic code. As a result, mutations play a significant role in generating genetic diversity and are a driving force in the process of evolution.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Which statement explains why DNA is evidence of common ancestry?A.\hspace{1em}All organisms have an identical DNA base sequence.B.\hspace{1em}All organisms contain DNA.C.\hspace{1em}Closely related species contain the same alleles.D.\hspace{1em}More recently evolved species have more similar DNA.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct because the presence of DNA in all organisms reflects a universal lineage, providing evidence of common ancestry. All organisms use the same four nucleotides (adenine, thymine, cytosine, and guanine) and the same genetic code to translate DNA into proteins, which supports the idea of a shared evolutionary origin.Choice Ais incorrect because while all organisms share common sequences in their DNA, their base sequences are not identical. Differences in DNA sequences accumulate over time, and species with more recent common ancestors have more similar DNA.Choice Cis incorrect because organisms that are closely related share many similarities in their DNA but their alleles are not all identical.Choice Dis incorrect because all organisms, living and extinct, contain DNA, not only recently evolved species.

list.title: Question 24
list.content: What characteristic of DNA allows it to serve as a template for both DNA replication and mRNA synthesis?A.\hspace{1em}The genetic code in DNA is universal across all organismsB.\hspace{1em}Hydrogen bonding enables the correct alignment of deoxyribonucleotides and ribonucleotides in newly synthesised strandsC.\hspace{1em}DNA’s double helix structure means one strand can be replicated at the same time as the other is being transcribedD.\hspace{1em}The strong sugar-phosphate backbone
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Bis correct. During both replication and transcription, nucleotides are aligned along the DNA template strand according to base-pairing rules. Hydrogen bonds form between the nitrogenous bases of the template DNA strand and the incoming deoxyribonucleotides (during replication) or ribonucleotides (in transcription).The genetic code being universal means that the same codons code for the same amino acids in all organisms. However, this relates to protein synthesis, not to how DNA acts as a template for replication or transcription;Choice Ais incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect because replication and transcription can’t occur on opposite strands simultaneously.Choice Dis incorrect because while the sugar-phosphate backbone is a feature of both DNA and RNA strands that provides structural stability, it does not explain how DNA can interact with both DNA and RNA nucleotides.
